en.value: They're very proud of their son.
She was determined to swim to the other side and she did.
I am confident about my ability.
We are so excited to hear you're moving to Australia!
She is a very enthusiastic person. Always so positive about things.
He's no longer arrogant, but he's very ambitious.
If I had taken my jacket, I would have been more comfortable at the campsite.
She was very disappointed with her exam results.
He seems to be exhausted all of the time now.
Some people were offended by the content of the book.
They spent an anxious week waiting for the test results.
Maria felt guilty for being so jealous of her sister.
I have been terrified of the dark since I saw that film.
Using various adjectives to express how you feel
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
We've finally completed the project! Don't you feel [k]proud[/k]?
Yes, I do, but I feel more relaxed than anything else.
Me too, it was hard work. Hopefully the boss will be satisfied now as well.
I hope so! I sometimes get the impression she thinks we are not capable but I think she's [k]confident[/k] about this project.
I feel [k]determined[/k] to work hard with the next project now.
Yes but we need to remember that it won't be easy!
Let's go out and celebrate our success.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Why aren't you and Charlie speaking to each other?
He says that he feels [k]hurt[/k] by what I said to him. What do you think I should do?
What did you say? does he have any reasons to be [k]upset[/k]?
I said that he hasn't been doing a good job recently, but I was only joking!
That wasn't a good idea! he's been [k]terrified[/k] of losing his job lately! The boss keeps saying he needs to work harder!
I didn't realise. If I had known, I wouldn't have said anything that might upset him.
Maybe it would be a good idea to go and apologise to him.
You've got a point, he's probably really [k]anxious[/k] now...
Think about a period in your life when you had a bad feeling. What happened? How did you feel?

When I was at university I failed an exam because I didn't revise enough. I was upset because I'd failed, but disappointed and angry with myself because I knew that if I had revised more and tried harder, I would have passed.
You've been to Spain, haven't you?
You had a good time though; you looked like you did.
She looks so happy, doesn't she?

The questions below are tag questions. Question tags get added to a statement for two reasons: 1. To find out information we are not sure about 2. When we know the answer, and want keep the conversation going Tag questions are common in spoken English.

You've been to Spain, haven't you?
She looks so happy, doesn't she?
The speaker is not sure of the answer to the question they're asking. (Tip: You need to listen to the sentence)
You're not feeling well today, are you?
You used to work there, didn't you?
The new house looks amazing, doesn't it?

When we are using tag questions to continue the conversation (i.e. we know the answer), we use falling intonation on the tag. When we don't know the answer, we use rising intonation on the question tag.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
You went to school near here,
You won't be at the party,
Positive statements have a negative tag, negative statements have a positive tag:
You love him, don't you? You don't love him, do you?
In the tag we use the auxiliary verb and a pronoun:
The food is great, isn't it? not* <strike>The food is great, isn't the food?</strike>
You're not coming tonight, are you?
You'd like a cup of tea, wouldn't you?
You get a lot of rain in this area, don't you?
You were walking to work at the time, weren't you?
You haven't seen this film before, have you?
You'll help me with the project, won't you?
In answers to tag questions we usually use just the auxiliary verb with the pronoun. We don't use the contracted form with positive answers.:

A: You're not coming, are you? 
B: No, I'm not. / Yes, I am
not* <strike>Yes, I'm.</strike>
We've run out of milk, [k]haven't we[/k]?
We were there last year, [k]weren't we[/k]?
You would agree with that, [k]wouldn't you[/k]?
You run to work every day, [k]don't you[/k]?
You are trying your best, [k]aren't you[/k]?
Fill in the gap using the hint.
They've helped us a lot, [k]haven't they[/k]?
The food didn't taste good, [k]did it[/k]?
